concept.title: How detailed should a topic be?
concept.shortdesc: A DITA topic should be as short as possible, but as long as is necessary to convey its information independently.

conbody.p: The amount of information per topic within a publication is sometimes referred to as topic granularity. A DITA topic should contain just one idea or answer a single question.

In some cases, a topic may be extremely short, as in the following example of an emergency procedure for a jet fighter aircraft. <task> <title>Engine failure below 10,000 feet</title> <taskbody> <steps> <step><cmd>Eject.</cmd></step> </steps> </taskbody> </task>

In other cases, a topic describing a very complex procedure, a very complex concept, an extensive glossary, or a lengthy reference table, may be the equivalent of many pages long. For example, a reference topic listing all the makes and models of cars of the 20th century is very lengthy, but still covers just one subject.
A topic should be as short as possible, but long enough to be independent of other topics. In other words, it must make sense on its own in any context.

section.title: Rationale

lq.reftitle: Deborah Pickett, Yahoo! DITA Users Group
lq.p: I could be facile and say that a topic needs as much detail as a piece of string needs length, but there's often a bit of flexibility in a system, and it's probably up to you (as your company's information architect) to make an executive decision. The good news is that since it's all XML, if you find later that your decision was wrong then it isn't too difficult to refactor the content.

For a lot of user documentation, both re-use and one-idea-per-topic tend to dictate the same amount of granularity. That's not by accident; topic-based authoring came about partly to make those two requirements roughly equivalent.
But DITA is sometimes used for things that aren't so obviously user documentation. DITA-OT has a sample plugin that demonstrates topics describing Java APIs. There's quite a bit of nesting of topics.

lq.reftitle: Ben David, Yahoo! DITA Users Group

section.lq: "A topic should be like a woman's skirt - long enough to cover the essentials, and short enough to maintain interest."
